awd_titl_txt: CAREER:Coordination of neural activity during memory formation in humans
awd_abstract_narration:
Memory disorders affect millions of Americans today. Despite decades of work, we have little ability to prevent, improve or treat such memory disorders. With the support of the National Science Foundation, Dr. Ueli Rutishauser and colleagues are investigating how humans form, store, and retrieve memories. The research supported by this CAREER award is to observe the electrical activity of brain cells in the hippocampus, an area essential for the formation of new memories. This research is performed with human patients who are undergoing surgery to treat epilepsy. To localize seizures, these patients are implanted with small wires in different parts of their brain, which allows researchers to investigate the human nervous system at the cellular level. Using this technique, we will investigate how human brain cells change when new memories are formed. Specifically, we will test whether the formation of new memories is dependent on a brain rhythm called the "theta oscillation", and if disruptions of this rhythm lead to poor memory.  Critically, theta oscillations can be changed by electrical stimulation, which offers a potential technique to improve memory.  Through education, teaching, and mentoring, this CAREER award will enable new researchers and organizations to take advantage of the extremely valuable opportunities for basic research on the human nervous system presented by intracranial electrophysiology. 

The research objective of this CAREER award is to investigate the neural mechanisms of human declarative memory at the level of individual neurons and circuits. We work with patients implanted with micro-wire electrodes who volunteer to participate in this research. The objective is to understand how the activity of networks of neurons is coordinated such that their collective action results in plasticity and long-term memories. We test the hypothesis that hippocampal theta oscillations mediate this process by combining human single-neuron recordings, behavioral testing, electrical stimulation, and computational modelling. This approach will allow us to assess the role and necessity of oscillations for the formation of human memories and thereby demonstrate the role of a specific oscillation in human cognition. We study i) how the activity of two distinct functional types of hippocampal neurons that we identified (visual and memory selective) are modulated by the theta rhythm; ii) how modulation of theta oscillations by shifts in spatial attention impacts individual neurons; and iii) whether there is a causal link between theta oscillations and memory strength. This study could provide, for the first time, a link between the cellular mechanisms of plasticity, oscillations, and human memory. The educational objective is to closely involve students in all aspects of the research, and to incorporate research results into classes, workshops and a K-12 outreach program. The resulting methods, tools, and datasets will be publicly released.

por.por_cntn:
The ability to rapidly form, store, and retrieve large numbers of memories is a hallmark of human cognition. However, it remains poorly understood how individual neurons within the human memory system contribute to encoding and retrieving memories, and how different neurons coordinate their activity among each other during these processes. Here, as part of a comprehensive research program, we combined behavioral experiments, invasive neurophysiological recordings and computational models to shed light on how the human brain forms and retrieves memories.

We used the unique opportunity to directly listen to the activity of individual brain cells in the human brain of patients undergoing surgery to treat epilepsy. We did so primarily in the hippocampus, an area of the brain critical for the formation of new declarative memories.  We examined how the formation of new memories and the retrieval of existing memories is facilitated by a brain rhythm called the "theta oscillation". Theta is known to be critical for coordinating activity among groups of neurons involved in encoding memories, but its exactly role remains little understood in humans.

Key outcomes of this grant include a characterization of the properties of human theta, identification of a new combined rate-phase code by which theta facilitated the encoding of working memories, the discovery that theta phase resets triggered by eye movements, which reflect the focus of attention, happen preferentially when we look at social stimuli such as faces, and identification of a role of theta in routing information retrieved from memory to the frontal cortex to facilitate memory-based decision making. Together, this new mechanistic knowledge (all of which is now published in peer-reviewed journals) on the role of theta in human memory provides a detailed circuit-level view of how human memory is implemented. A key broader impact of this work is that it provides new knowledge that might make it possible to develop much needed new treatments for memory disorders through modulation of theta oscillations in the human brain via deep brain stimulation.

Work enabled by this award has led to multiple lectures, public outreach and lectures at a local middle school, and the development of a new class at Caltech. Also, this award has enabled mentorship, training, and career development for several high school students, undergraduates, graduate students, and postdoctoral fellows. Several of these individuals have now gone on to graduate school, medical school,  college or have started their own labs, thereby demonstrating the positive impact of the mentorship opportunity enabled by this grant. A key goal of this grant was to support the organization of the human single neuron meeting, which we have organized successfully in 2016, 2018, and 2020 and which has been positively received in the community, thereby contributing to the development of this new emerging field of research.
